nodes.text: When a person is induced to state or do something contrary to a private opinion, he will tend to change his private opinion to align with the overt behavior, and the greater the extrinsic reward beyond what is necessary to induce the behavior, the smaller the subsequent opinion change
Prior studies (Janis and King) showed improvising a speech contrary to private opinion can shift private opinion toward the speech, attributed by authors to mental rehearsal and generating arguments

Kelman reported that larger rewards produced less opinion change than smaller rewards, an effect that aligns with the cognitive dissonance derivation but had interpretive problems due to self-selection

Festinger's cognitive dissonance framework: dissonance arises when cognitions are inconsistent, total dissonance magnitude is a function of dissonances divided by dissonances plus consonances, and increasing external justification (rewards or threats) reduces net dissonance driving attitude change

Method: Laboratory experiment with 71 male introductory psychology students assigned to Control, One Dollar, or Twenty Dollar conditions; subjects performed boring tasks, then either did not or were asked to tell a waiting subject the tasks were enjoyable and were paid accordingly; private opinions measured later by blind interviewer on four scaled questions
Sample and exclusions: final analysis used 60 subjects (20 per condition); 11 subjects excluded for suspicion, refusal to be hired or to accept payment, or admitting deception

Primary dependent measure: rating of how enjoyable the tasks were (scale -5 to +5); secondary measures: desire to participate again (-5 to +5), perceived scientific importance (0 to 10), and how much learned (0 to 10)

Result (enjoyability): One Dollar group mean = +1.35, Control = -0.45, Twenty Dollar = -0.05; One Dollar > Control significant at p=0.02, One Dollar > Twenty Dollar significant at p=0.03; Twenty Dollar not significantly different from Control

Result (desire to participate): pattern same direction as enjoyability (One Dollar highest), but differences weaker and only marginally significant (One Dollar vs Control p~0.08; One Dollar vs Twenty Dollar p~0.15)

Result (scientific importance and learning): scientific importance slightly higher in One Dollar than Twenty Dollar (marginal p~0.08), otherwise small or negligible differences; how much learned showed no meaningful differences across conditions

Evidence against alternative explanation of increased mental rehearsal: tape-recorded conversations were transcribed and rated blind on content, persuasiveness, and time spent; raters showed good reliability and ratings indicated Twenty Dollar scores slightly higher, so One Dollar subjects did not improvise more convincingly

Conclusion: The experimental pattern—greater attitude change in low extrinsic reward condition relative to high reward and control—supports the cognitive dissonance prediction that insufficient external justification produces larger private opinion change
Limitation: Exclusion of 11 of 71 subjects for suspicion or noncompliance reduces sample and may affect generality; some excluded subjects indicated awareness of the manipulation
